In the prosecution of the civil war, the prince of Ionia twice returned to Europe ; joined his arms with those of the emperor 3 besieged Thessalonica, and threatened Constantinople. Calumny might affix some reproach on his imper- fest aid, his hasty departure, and a bribe of ten thousand crowns, which he accepted from the Byzantine court; but his friend was sa- tisfied3 and the conduct of Amir is excused by the more sacred duty of defending against the Latins his hereditary dominions.
